author: kalgiz
body:
Add -AsArray parameter to ConvertoTo-Json command to always pack the output string in array brackets, even if the input is a single object.

Resolve issue: https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/6327

comments.author: rjmholt
comments.body:
It looks like `ConvertTo-Json -AsArray 1,2` actually produces
```
[
  [
    1,
    2
  ]
]
```
and not the expected
```
[
  1,
  2
]
```

The `-ShouldBeLike` tests don't pick that up, but I played with them, and without maybe a switch on the `ConvertTo-Json` cmdlet to omit whitespace, I'm not sure how we would make them use `-ShouldBeExactly` cross-platform. Either that or a more complicated regex (not very in favour of that but it might be what we need).

comments.author: markekraus
comments.body:
@rjmholt I would expect `ConvertTo-Json -AsArray 1,2` to return `[[1,2]]`. There are plenty of APIs that accept an array of arrays where the outer array may contain 0 or more inner arrays. 

The current behavior of `ConvertTo-Json 1,2` is `[1,2]` which means when I need to send `[[1,2]]` I have to do some string manipulation of my own.

comments.author: rjmholt
comments.body:
Ah, I misinterpreted the description of expected behaviour in #6372 -- missed the pipeline flattening part. Agree that this behaves as expected in that context.

Not sure if there's a way to change the tests to make them more discriminating.

But this looks good!
